html:
Etymology[edit]

Borrowed from Frankish *bastijan (“to sew, weave”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈbas.ti.oː/, [ˈbas.t̪i.oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈbas.ti.o/, [ˈbas.t̪i.ɔ]

Verb[edit]

bastiō (present infinitive bastīre, perfect active bastīvī, supine bastītum); fourth conjugation

  1. (Medieval Latin) I build, construct
  2. (Medieval Latin) I sew, weave

Derived terms[edit]

  • bastimentum

Descendants[edit]

  • Old French: bastir
    • Middle French: bastir
      • French: bâtir
        • Haitian Creole: bati
    • Norman: baïr
    • Picard: bâti
    • Walloon: bati (Liégeois), bâti (Charleroi)
    • → Middle English: basten
      • English: baste
  • Italian: bastire
  • Old Occitan: bastir
    • Catalan: bastir
    • Occitan: bastir
  • Old Portuguese: bastir
    • Portuguese: bastir
  • Spanish: bastir
